* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>

Thanks for the review!

> Can be a followup PR, but it'd be nice if the docs in Matroid.Restrict and Matroid.Constructions linked to the def here.
> 
> I wonder if `loopyOn` should be defined in this file too.
> 
> I'll look at this again after you've made the change we discussed above, to save us both some potential duplicate work!

It would be a little annoying to move `loopyOn`, since it is used in the definition of `freeOn`, which then would cause quite a few things unrelated to loops to depend on the content of this file. I've added references to `IsLoop` in earlier docstrings as you suggest. 

(I also cleaned up a bunch of silly `Restriction` -> `IsRestriction`-related typos in the `Matroid.Restrict` module docstring, which I hope you can permit as a reviewer).

Can be a followup PR, but it'd be nice if the docs in Matroid.Restrict and Matroid.Constructions linked to the def here. 

I wonder if `loopyOn` should be defined in this file too.

I'll look at this again after you've made the change we discussed above, to save us both some potential duplicate work!

Can be a followup PR, but it'd be nice if the docs in Matroid.Restrict and Matroid.Constructions linked to the def here. 

I wonder if `loopyOn` should be defined in this file too.

I'll look at this again after you've made the change we discussed above, to save us both some potential duplicate work!
Bearing this in mind, I wonder if it's any easier to define M.loops as this set, and use the spelling of being in that set for the predicate of being a loop. What do you think?

I considered this. (I think) the reason I didn't do this for my repo is so that the set of loops was more transparently something I could apply closure lemmas to. But it looks like I have helper lemmas like `loops_subset_closure` to abstract these uses out anyway. So this is probably a good idea for saving keystrokes as well as clarity. I'l make the change.
It would be nice to state this using `TFAE`, and might save you some rewrites in practice
